text:
Thank you for having me. It's wonderful to
see a full room. I know we are just two
weeks into your quarter.

That is the case for us
as well at Georgia Tech. And excited to share
some of this journey

that Michael was referring to. And as you can see from
the title of my talk, I will be reflecting
a little bit

on what is this relationship
that we have been pondering over many years
now, and can we get

a little bit of a
handle on that question by leaning on
evidence that comes

from actual observational
data of people? Before I get
started, I would note that we are talking
about mental health here.

So I do have a content warning. If anybody needs to step out,
please feel free to do so. I wouldn't mind at all.

All right. So outside of computing, my
favorite topic area is history.

So that's what I'm
going to start. Not too many years ago, I'm
just talking about 1989,

at what is called CERN or
the European Organization for Nuclear Research,
Tim Berners-Lee

came up with what
eventually became the Web. Of course, that
innovation of Berners-Lee

was not the first of its kind
that intended to connect people, but largely to help
people share information

and data with each other. An obscure version
of the Web existed in the form of what we still
sometimes use interchangeably

with the Web,
called the internet. And that was actually developed
back in the 1960s as a part

of advanced research
agency, or DARPA. And at that point in time, the
purpose of this new technology

was so that scientists can
share files with each other when they're not sitting
next to each other.

But Berners-Lee's invention
was a little bit different. It was different because
what he decided to do

was to release the source
code of this tool for free. And ever since then,
we know that the Web

has taken a life of its own. But of course, from
the very beginning,

its creator, Berners-Lee,
knew that this technology can wield immense power
and influence in our lives.

Of course, his prophecy
came to fruition, I would say, over
the years, as we

saw that how deeply Web
and its technologies are now intertwined
in our lives.

We have an entire
new set of terms that we are familiar with today. We call young people
digital natives

because that's what
they grew up with. And we know how
people go to the web to find or meet their needs that
otherwise could remain unmet.

We have seen the role of
certain technologies on the Web, I'm talking of social
technologies that have had,

I would say, a lot of
accidental and incidental uses, whether in bringing people
together in supporting activism

and supporting social
movements and the list goes on. But at the same time,
Berners-Lee also

knew that this tool can have
a lot of negative impacts

in the world as well. And we have plenty of examples
of that over the years.

Whether it is thinking
about some of the harms that are caused-- that the
social media platforms are

causing in the form
of or disinformation, whether it is in the
form of privacy breaches

that have happened or continue
to happen over the years. Or whether it is about
misuse or abuse of data,

especially people's information
that they leave behind on these platforms that were
used beyond intended purposes.

But of course, these benefits
and harms of Web tools

or technologies or social
media in particular with respect to the
stock, were not just the thinking of its creator.

In fact, scholars over
the last 20, 25 years have been asking
these same questions, and we have seen lots of great
examples of how social media

platforms are
benefiting our lives. We have seen time to time the
positives that social media

platforms bring in our lives,
whether it is helping us during major life events,
whether it is giving voice

to marginalized communities,
or whether it is helping people seek information on
experiences and needs

that they may not be able
to fulfill elsewhere.

But at the same time, we
also see news every day. And we read about how
certain social media

platforms are causing mental
health challenges in people. How online streaming networks
are glorifying aspects

such as suicide, and we hear
about the stresses and anxieties that parents and
lawmakers have in terms

of what do we do now
about all of these harms? What is the right
approach going forward?

In fact, it is now a
question of culture war, and it is a question
that is very much part

of the popular discourse. We have a whole book
that was written on the harms of social
media in the last year.

And the challenges
have been so grave that a year and a half
back, the US Surgeon General

issued an advisory
that encouraged us to think about these
technologies in a way that

actually would enable
or allow people to build social connection
rather than harm.

And I had a chance to
contribute to that report in order to provide that
researcher perspective

and bringing that evidence to
bear on this important question.

But you might be wondering,
why does everybody love to talk about this question? Well, of course, it's a
question that impacts our lives.

It's important. But other than that, also
because the answers evade us.

Let me tell you a little
bit about the knowledge gaps in this area. One of the first things
that we have to acknowledge

is that most of our
understanding of the benefits and harms of these
platforms are largely based on what people say to
be those benefits and harms.

Nothing wrong in that,
but sometimes we over or underestimate those
benefits and harm.

Or maybe we misremember. So this overreliance on
self-reports and social media

use has given us some
broad understanding of the impact of
these platforms,

but a lot of questions
remain, right? What is use after all?

And user has been a
topic of grave importance within the human computer
interaction community,

but so I think should use be. What does use really mean here? And we are still
asking that question.

And it's very
relevant when you're trying to understand does
use impact benefits or harms.

The second challenge
is that we don't have as many studies
in this area that

are relying on ecologically
valid information or ecologically valid data.

Outside of what
people self-report, what is actually transpiring or
happening on these platforms?

We don't have a very
good handle on that. And when we do, it's often based
on the public social media data,

which many platforms
allow public interaction, but many platforms don't.

And if we truly
want to understand what impact these platforms are
having on our mental health, we need to take a more
holistic approach.

But probably and
most importantly, the evidence that we have
today largely is correlational.
What are we trying to do here? We are trying to help people. We want to amplify the benefits.

We want to mitigate the harm. And we can take action in
the form of interventions only when we understand what
is driving those changes.

It's an inherently
causal question. But unfortunately, most of the
data that we have as of today

are correlational
rather than causal. And then finally,
there are questions

of not just what use really
means but what is social media. That is often the first lecture
in my social computing class,

and year after
year I see we never have an agreed upon definition. And that's not a negative.

That's just the nature of
this ever-evolving technology. So if you're trying to
answer the question of does

social media help or
hurt our mental health, we have to also ask
the question first, what do we mean by
social media and what

affordances of these
platforms are impacting us in positive or negative ways.

And finally, there are
ethical challenges. Of course, we are talking
about a very sensitive topic here mental health.

We are talking about
potentially people what happens transpires
in private contexts

on these platforms. So how do we navigate
ethical challenges as we seek to address all
of those knowledge gaps?

In my work, I seek to
address those challenges by taking a view that none
of the biggest challenges

and questions in the world
can be solved by people from one discipline alone.

How do we bring that
philosophy and perspective in the work we do? At Georgia Tech, I lead the
social dynamics and well-being

lab, and I feel that to answer
questions in this field, we need people from
different disciplines to work together in a way that
enables learning that transcends

disciplinary boundaries. But at the same time, how do we
do this work that fundamentally

is human centered? Because after all, who
are we trying to help? The people.

And those people need to be part
of that conversation of figuring out what these benefits or
what these harms could be.

With that goal in mind,
in order to answer this question of does
social media help or hurt

mental health, over
the last few years, we have been pursuing
a philosophy of how

can we center these
investigations by working together with not just
interdisciplinary scholars,

but also people with the lived
experience of mental health challenges, or people who
have benefited or been

harmed by these technologies. Here is a screenshot
of a system that we have been incrementally building
on over the last few years.

And it's based on this
simple philosophy, what if we imagined a world
in which people can

donate their data for science. And this would create eventually
a resource on which we can not

only ask and answer all
those questions about does social media use impact
mental health but also

help us address many of
those knowledge gaps. Whether it is about
correlation versus causation,

what use means, what social
media affordances mean, and so on. Over the years, the system has
been developed with support

from a number of sponsors,
both federal and private.

And at the crux of this
system is a legislation which

allows this to even happen. And that's within European
Union, the GDPR legislation,

which in simple terms
asks any platform,

any tech company who
has a social technology and is doing business
in the EU needs

to give agency to its
user in the following way. So users should be able
to go to these platforms

and download an
archive of their data. Because of GDPR, most of the
major platforms and examples

are included on the supported
sites on that slide are allowing people to download
their data, and we

are harnessing that feature
in this idea of donating data for science. But of course, it is
also really important

that people feel comfortable
in donating their data, because some of these
data are inherently very private and sensitive.

So what we have done is
an iterative approach in which we work with them
through a series of scenarios

and educational guides that
would allow them to understand how their data potentially
could be used in order to ask

or answer these questions
about social media use and mental health. And you see some
screenshots of how

we explain complex constructs
such as social support, depression, or
suicidal ideation that

could be inferred from
social media interactions to these end users.

Of course, there are
many things that we need to ensure other
than working together

on this transparency question. And these are questions
of who the person is.

Is this person an
adult or a minor? There are legal aspects that
we need to tackle over here.

So we are currently
using this platform to also recruit from teenagers
who are considered minor

within the American definition
of study populations. So in developing
this platform, we

have had to spend lots and lots
of cycles, not just because of ethical review that
was fairly complex,

but also working
with law enforcement, working with legal
scholars, and so on.

And I'm going to give you
some examples of the things that we have done. For instance, we have
obtained an NIH Certificate

of Confidentiality. So that the data that is
collected through this platform cannot be subpoenaed in
a lawsuit going forward.

And that's one way to ensure
protection of our research subjects. And then we have also worked
with a continuous consent

process in which a person who
wants their data to go away from the system going forward
has a clear and easy way

to do that. So the front end is pretty
simple of the system. I'm going to talk a little
bit about the back end.

The back end looks like this. It's a high level
infrastructure. There is a public
facing aspect to it.

And then there is a part
of the back end that is behind a firewall
that is access

control through the
principle of least privilege. And we have an automated
way of de-identifying

the data to the extent possible. So that is another aspect
that we communicate and work

with the study participants. So I'm not going to spend too
much on the infrastructure.

I'm happy to answer
questions going forward. But what I can say is
till now, this system

has been used in various
incarnations for a number of different projects. Right now it's ongoing
data collection

on six different projects most
of which are funded by the NIH. And it has been used in the
context of different study

populations. You'll see some examples
of that in my talk today, and also a number of different
platforms and types of questions

about mental health. But what is one of the big sort
of advantageous of this kind

of data collection? So those of you who are aware
what kind of study designs

are possible, essentially with
this kind of retrospective data collection, the kind
of studies you can do

could be described as
case control studies. So essentially, you
have a population

of interest, which has
certain attributes, and you have another
population, which

would be control where those
attributes would be absent. This is retrospective data.

So going backwards. What you can do is you
can learn about what

kind of exposures
or risk factors can precipitate a
certain outcome. In concrete terms, if you see
on the figure on the right, what

this means is that in your
cases and your controls, you can see which kind of risk
factors are present or absent.

And the assumption
is that the cases would have a certain
risk factor more

prevalent than in the controls. And then you can over
time, because this data

has longitudinal
stablish or seek to establish a causal
relationship between what those factors are and
what your outcome is.

In concrete terms, those factors
could be different aspects or dimensions of social
media use or experience,

and your outcome could
be your mental health. So with that kind of
case control design,

I'm going to give you
some examples, drawing on our prior work that
hopefully would give you

a glimpse of the kinds of
questions that you can answer, all of which get to that
central bigger topic of what

are the benefits and harms
of these platforms when it comes to mental health.

My personal position
on this topic is that the answer
is very complex.

And hopefully, you would believe
that by the end of the talk. So I'm going to give
you some examples to start off with that
showcases the benefits

that these platforms
could be offering. I'll move on to a
project that would

show how these platforms could
be hurting mental health. I'll get to that question of why
this is so hard and complicated,

and we still don't know the
answer through another project. And then what are some of
the paths forward from here?

So the first one is about, let's
talk about good things first.

So the question
that we are asking, if we drill down more into
what social media use can mean

and what mental health
can mean, here we are asking a simple question
about a kind of social media

use that is pretty common. People come to these
platforms and they like to talk about
different life events.

Those life events can be
positive, can be negative. Those could be things that
have already happened,

things that could happen in
the near future going forward,

and so on. And this is platform agnostic,
obviously, some platforms people

do that more often
than others, but we see that to happen in a
lot of different places.

People are clearly doing that. Although nobody who built
these platforms back in, I don't 2005 was thinking
that these platforms will

be used for this purpose. But here we are. People are using them. What kind of benefits
are they getting?

Clearly they're
getting some benefits. There must be some good thing
that comes out of that sharing. Can we quantify and
understand that good.

And is that good good for the
person's mental health or not. And how do we establish
that causal relationship

between disclosing a life
event on social media platform, and then the person's mental
well-being going forward?

The data for this study
came from a multimodal study that we ran a few years ago.

This was a huge
collaboration funded by the [INAUDIBLE] involving
seven different institutions and used an incarnation of
social media data collection

system that I just
introduced to you earlier. And here's a list of various
data that we collected.

But we not going to touch on
some of the wearable data that was collected in this process.

I would also note
that to my knowledge, this is the largest
multicenter study that has ever been conducted so far.

It enrolled over
750 participants and the whole thing
ran for a year.

We had people. There was a skew towards US, but
there were people from outside

of the US as well. For the purposes
of this study, I'm going to be talking about
Facebook data, which

was one of the data streams. And this data was timeline
data that was over a year

long period. So it included both public and
private posts or anything that shows up on their timeline.

And then we had a variety
of self-reported information throughout the study. But the one that
is most relevant

here is the
self-reported life event data through a validated scale
called the PERI life event

scale. So here the study is on
a subset of this data, 240 participants out of the 757.

And so with the PERI
life event scale, we essentially had
some kind of a baseline

of the different things that
happened in a person's life. I would note that we are
not assuming that the survey

data is the ground truth here,
and I'll come to that why. But essentially you can imagine
that we had all the information

about life event
disclosures that were happening on social
media and ones that were reported on the survey
responses to the scale.

So you don't have to go a little
bit or go much deeper into this. On the very left,
you have a rundown

of the different covariates. So we did collect a
lot of information about individual level
traits, whether it's

personality or cognitive ability
of these individuals other than demographic attributes. But I'll jump over to
talking about the life of

and disclosures on social media. So we developed a
theoretically informed codebook

to qualitatively
annotate life events in these Facebook postings
of our participants.

And you can see some of the
examples of types of event.

What were some of the
conditions or rules within the codebook that
were used for this purpose.

Some examples, and so on. At the end of it, we had a
nice looking distribution

of life event
disclosures on Facebook. And predictably, it's a
heavy tailed distribution

that you see on the top right. Of course, there is a skew
towards positive events being

talked about on Facebook,
like vacations and trips and social stuff, and then
some of the negative ones

are more down below, for
instance, injury, and so on. We also have a comparison
between what people

felt comfortable
disclosing on Facebook and what they felt comfortable
disclosing in the survey.

And that's what you see
in the bottom right. And clearly there
are differences.

There is always
bias in survey data. We always knew that. But there is bias in
social media data.

There is bias everywhere. And this is what
the fuller picture looks like if you
combine, look at both.

So in order to
answer that question of why people were
going to these platforms to talk about these life
events, let's talk a little bit

about what they were getting
in return from their friends. How did the audience engage
with that information?

And here are some simple
statistical analysis of reactions and comments.

And if you see life events
referred to as LE in this slide,

they get more reactions
and more comments compared to other postings,
and that difference is statistically significant.

But there are some
differences across types of events if you just look
at the valence dimension.

There are some
nuances there also. For instance, we see that
positive life events get

way more reactions
than any of-- compared to comments for negative
life events, it's equal.

But still there are more
reactions than comments. And for neutral we see
quite a bit of skew.

And all of those differences
across categories are statistically significant.

So now the question
is clearly they are getting a variety
of different reactions, but are those reactions actually
having a positive or negative

impact on their mental health. Because that is
the causal question that we intended to
answer at the beginning?

So we leaned on the causal
inference literature from statistics, and
I'm going to give you

some hands on feel about what
the kind of methodology we used here. So essentially what you have
is there was an intervention.

The intervention is the person-- the event was the
person disclosed

a life event, which is that
vertical gray line over here. And the treatment
group are these people

who disclosed the life event. Your Y-axis in this case would
be their mental well-being

in the form of stress, anxiety,
which were the outcomes that were collected in this study. So ideally, if in
a perfect world,

you would also have
a control sample. You would have a set of people
who never disclosed any life

event on these platforms. We did not have that
in this data set.

What do you do? Turns out that you can
create counterfactuals. Counterfactuals are essentially
what the word means.

What would have happened if
this life event disclosure, if this event did not happen?

This is what the
diagram would look like if you build a
counterfactual, a synthetic,

a simulation of that
alternative reality. What you would do then
is post-intervention,

you would measure what is the
difference in your outcome between the reality,
which is the treatment,

and your synthetic,
counterfactual. And that gap would be your
treatment effect, that would

be that causal explanation. Because if you see that gap
you know that the intervention

has had an impact. So we created two kinds of
counterfactuals in this work

because we didn't
have a real control. The first counterfactual was
one, in which you actually

work with your treatment group
up till the point of the life

event disclosure. You build a time series
prediction model, and you assume that whatever
was the trend on your Y-axis--

on your X-axis sorry,
Y-axis that would continue to hold past that intervention
if this intervention did not

happen. So if that intervention
did not happen, your red line would continue
to look like, going up.

But in reality,
maybe what you see is that it is higher
than that counterfactual.

Again, that is the gap
you're hoping to measure. We also used a second kind
of counterfactual here, which

is that you could
argue maybe there was something weird about the
time at which this disclosure

happened. And maybe the
effect that you see is not because of the
disclosure of the life event,

but it's because of some
other external confounder that just happened to happen
at that point in time.

Maybe there are
seasonal effects. Maybe there are other
hidden variables that we don't know
and have not measured.

So to tackle that you can adopt
another set of counterfactuals, which are called
placebo interventions.

So these are not
real interventions. But you're assuming that
these interventions happened at different points in time.

What if you could create
different versions of a reality where you permute the time,
which is on the X-axis,

and then you assume that
this event, this intervention

could have happened at any
of those randomized times. So you randomize the time
stamps, you take the midpoint,

let's say in this
case, and you assume that's when the life
event disclosure happened, except that it did not. It's a placebo.

So if that real life
event disclosure would have any impact on
your outcome to your right,

you would not see that in
those permuted time series. And that's what we
are doing here, which

is the second counterfactual. So now that I've
given you a little bit of a background of the method,
let's look at what we found.

So the overall story here
is that when people choose

to disclose a life
event on Facebook, it makes a difference to their
mental health compared to when

they don't. And how do we know
when they don't? Because we have that
survey, remember.

So we have very rich
data of life events when people choose to
disclose them on Facebook,

and when they did not choose
to disclose them on Facebook. And do we see differences
across those two?

So what happens when
people disclose? When it is a positive
life event, when

people disclose on
Facebook, it leads to reduced negative affect.

It leads to reduced
stress, reduced anxiety, and better sleep, which is at
the bottom right of the slide.

But for those
events, when people choose not to
disclose on Facebook, we see that it actually leads to
greater negative affect, greater

stress, and then worsened sleep. Of course, there
are some differences

across the categories over here. You can also see when people
disclose negative events.

And one of the reasons why we
see that there is a heavy skew and bias towards not disclosing
as many negative events

is because when they
do that, it actually worsens the negative
affect to sorry--

it actually improves
the negative affect. We see a reduction in the
average treatment effect.

So what we are seeing over here
is that there are differences

across when people choose to
disclose and when they don't. People make that decision
and there are differences.

Usually when people
choose to disclose a life event on Facebook,
broadly speaking,

if you average across all of
those mental health outcomes, you see that
overall it is better

in terms of affect,
stress, anxiety, and sleep than it was before.

Similarly for negative events,
it also helps to disclose,

even though people
feel that they may not want to disclose negative
events as much on Facebook.

And we see that there is a huge
reduction in negative affect, stress, and anxiety,
and improvement in sleep

when they do make that somewhat
rare decision of disclosing a negative event on Facebook.

Yes. Sure. This is fascinating. Am I reading this right, that
if you disclose a positive life

event on Facebook,
it actually is associated with decreases in
experience of positive affect.

That is the only exception. If you look at the
other metrics-- you're right. You're reading it right.

And that's why it's in red. So the red bars here
mean that there is a worsening of mental health.

The blue color means that
there is an improvement, but the sign is also important. So you're right when we do see
a decrease in positive affect,

but we do see
significant reductions in negative affect,
stress, anxiety, and improvement in sleep.

And how do you understand the
decrease in positive affect? Usually, positive affect is
not as much of a clean signal

if you look at the
affect literature, maybe you're an expert. I am. [LAUGHTER]

After I said that I-- yeah, exactly. So we all know that positive
and negative effects are not

mirror images of each other. And that's exactly what
you're seeing here. And usually, the
measurement, and this

is a measurement problem is
that we see positive affect

to be not as clearly defined. Sometimes in measurement
we assume positive affect to be the absence
of negative affect,

although we know that
theoretically that's not correct. So I think that is what it's
a measurement problem that's

going on because stress,
anxiety, and sleep are much clearer signals here. And we see persistent
patterns for those.
Yeah. Good question. Yeah. All right.

Yeah I would like to wrap
up this part of the study, which is talking
about positive stuff.

And just to give you an example,
going back to those things that social media use
is not a monolith. And here we are looking at a
pretty narrow and pretty niche

kind of social media use, which
is actually pretty common, even though it's niche, which is
the disclosure of life events.

And that can have very
interesting relationships with a variety of
mental health outcomes.

And we looked at that in the
context of Facebook, of course, but that has its own affordances
in the form of reactions

and comments and has other set
of features which enable or not enable certain
kinds of activity.

But all of those things
are important pieces of consideration
and conversation as we attempt to make
progress on this question.

So speaking of the opposite
side of the spectrum, which is how does social media
use harm mental health.

The question that
we are asking here is a pervasive problem
that pretty much

every social media, users of
every social media platform experience.

And that's harassment. We know persistently that even
after 25 years of research

on harassment detection, we
haven't made a ton of progress. Even after 25 years of research
and content moderation,

it's still a question mark. Academically, intellectually,
and politically in front of us.

And so the question is,
what other solutions are possible in this space?

Two, a chart the universe of
those possible alternative interventions, we first
have to understand

how is harassment, when
it is not moderated or we are not able to
tackle it in some way,

what impact is it having
on people's mental health? Because once we understand
again that causal question,

we will be in a better position
to think about alternative ways of helping these people.

For this work, we
leaned on a data set that was also collected
in a similar way,

using an incarnation
of the platform I introduced at the very
beginning of the talk. It was an NSF-funded
study in collaboration

with the University of Central
Florida, and Vanderbilt, and Boston University. And what we were
interested in is

to curate a data set of
Instagram private conversations
coming from young people. And that included minors. That included teenagers.

And the idea here
was to really have that collaborative,
human centered approach to online safety research,
which was how do we

not just consent these
individuals to donate

their private
conversations, but also how do we have a better handle
of understanding what harassment

really means to these people? Because guess what? Harassment is a very
subjective personal experience.

So the system and the
approach that we used here was following pre-survey,
which is essentially

eligibility criteria
verification and consent. The participants took a range
of different validated surveys

on online risks. Then they donated or uploaded
their Instagram archive,

and then, they were invited to
flag conversations or messages

within the direct
messages on Instagram

helpful in supporting their

these social media platforms

were meeting a lot of needs. These people did not have
access to their phones, to social media for
a while, which are

very important in their lives. So this was a way,
easy way to reestablish some of those connections and

that they were

Why were you gone? They felt that they didn't

was important for them
for functional recovery after hospitalization. And this was speaking

based on a mixed method analysis

we did with these individuals. What this tells us
